sec.title: Background/Objectives
sec.p: The prevalence of chronic pain is high in patients with rheumatoid arthritis, increasing the risk for opioid use. The objective of this study was to assess disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drug (DMARD) use and its effect on long-term opioid use in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This cohort study included Medicare beneficiaries with diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis who received at least 30-day consecutive prescription of opioids in 2017 (n= 23,608). The patients were grouped into non-DMARD and DMARD users, which was further subdivided into regimens set forth by American College of Rheumatology. The outcome measured was long-term opioid use in 2018 defined as at least 90-day consecutive prescription of opioids. Dose and duration of opioid use were also assessed. A multivariable model identifying factors associated with non-DMARD use was also performed.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Compared to non-DMARD users, the odds of long-term opioid use were significantly lower among DMARD users (OR 0.89 95% CI 0.83, 0.95). All regimens except non-TNF Biologic + Methotrexate was associated with lower odds of long-term opioid use relative to non-DMARD users. The mean total MME, MME/day, and total days of opioid use were lower among DMARD users compared to non-DMARD users. Older age, males, Blacks, psychiatric and medical comorbidities, and not being seen by a rheumatologist were significantly associated with non-DMARD use.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: DMARD use was associated with lower odds of long-term opioid use among RA patients with baseline opioid prescription. Factors associated with non-DMARD use represent a window of opportunity for intervention to improve pain-related quality of life in patients living with rheumatoid arthritis.
